sections.abstract: Percutaneous dilational tracheostomy (PDT) is widely used in the ICU for airway management in patients with chronic respiratory failure or prolonged mechanical ventilation. Multiple techniques exist, with the single-dilator Ciaglia variant most commonly used. Flexible bronchoscopy is frequently employed as an adjunct and is associated with reduced complications compared with landmark-only techniques. Reported overall complication rates vary, with most being minor, and procedure-related mortality is low. PDT generally compares favorably with surgical tracheostomy with respect to procedure time, complications, and cost.
sections.methods: Narrative review describing PDT techniques, adjuncts (bronchoscopy, ultrasonography, laryngeal mask airway), procedure-related complications, and comparative data from published studies including randomized comparisons of different PDT techniques.
sections.results: Across studies summarized, bronchoscopy guidance during PDT was associated with a lower composite complication rate compared with non-bronchoscopic approaches in pooled nonrandomized data (16.8% vs 8.7%). Individual randomized comparisons among PDT techniques reported differences in specific complications (e.g., tracheal ring fracture, bleeding, hypoxemia), but head-to-head data are limited and findings are not uniform. Reported procedure-related mortality ranges from 0% to 0.7%, and bleeding from 0.4% to 8%, mostly minor.

population.text: Critically ill adults requiring tracheostomy for prolonged mechanical ventilation, airway protection, secretion management, or upper airway obstruction.
inclusion_criteria: Adults in ICU settings requiring tracheostomy for prolonged ventilation or airway management
exclusion_criteria: Not specified in this narrative review

intervention.details: Modified Seldinger approach; commonly Ciaglia single-dilator technique (Blue Rhino), with variations including multiple dilators, balloon dilation (Blue Dolphin), forceps (Griggs), translaryngeal, and rotational (PercuTwist); often performed with bronchoscopic guidance.

comparison.text: Surgical tracheostomy and alternative PDT techniques/adjuncts
comparison.details: Comparisons across literature include PDT vs surgical tracheostomy; within PDT, single vs multiple dilators, balloon dilation, forceps, translaryngeal, and rotational methods; bronchoscopy vs no bronchoscopy; ETT vs LMA during bronchoscopy-assisted PDT.

retrieval.summary_tldr: Narrative review: PDT, especially Ciaglia single-dilator with bronchoscopic guidance, is widely used in ICUs with low mortality (0-0.7%) and generally favorable complication profile vs surgical tracheostomy.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Supports bedside PDT as a safe, efficient airway procedure in the ICU, with bronchoscopy commonly recommended to reduce complications.
